content:
27, 2016
												I adored the first TDU. Hooning about Hawaii.When I got TDU2, I was quite happy. That changed when I started playing. Granted, it's open world. Granted, the scenery and the vehicle renderings are good. However, I don't have a steering wheel. I play with a joypad. And it took me ages to actually set the damn thing up to work as near as possible correctly. Once I'd done that, then the game became pretty decent. I enjoy the idea of passing the tests for various vehicle classes before you can proceed with various races to ultimately win the Solar Crown. Some of the races can prove challenging, so it's not all just a hoon about.Mooching around Ibiza and the jaunt to Hawaii, gives ample opportunity to find various vehicle dealers, small side quests, outfitters, hair dressers, plastic surgeon, real estate agents, and vehicle upgrade sites, both cosmetic and mechanic. The other racers in the game, that form the people you're pitted against are generally planks. Even though it's a game, there's a real sense of "I'm up here becuase I'm freakin fabulous, you're just a nothing", and it all seems to be about image. Hence the reason for the outfitters, hairdressers and plastic surgeon. Which I feel is ironic for a driving game.Graphically, it's very pretty, and the rendering internally of vehicle is quite good, although I wish the dash binnacle worked properly, not just the speedo and tacho. There's a good few MODs out there, and availability to add other, non stock vehicles to your garage is quite good. There's no Lamborghinis for example in the stock game. Apart from the initial niggles, TDU2 is a decent driving game, with lots of exploration, a decent choice of motors and a good place to while away many hours.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												I've probably played this game more than I ever played any other. The graphics are a bit dated now and the driving is more arcade than anything meaning the cars handle and perform nothing like the real things or even similar representations in other games. The road design is often better suited to a Need for Speed franchise where wrecking is purposely added and part of the whole atmosphere of the game. Some of the stuff you do in the game, things required to advance and otherwise, seem pointless and like "so what?" at best. Like clothes shopping and cosmetic surgery for a couple. Who really cares about either and most of the clothes are a joke and ridiculous beyond  belief. Many of the achievements needed to advance are very tedious and often require co-operation of other players. Good luck there both in finding enough players to help you and then finding enough good sports who'll actually help you. There's a casino DLC with its own blend of poker, slots, roulette and some players seem to prefer the casino to driving. Advancing through the different level cars requires a tiered licensing before you can buy the faster cars. The story is thin- you basically work your way through a racing series called Solar Crown using various class cars from old classics to high dollar exotics to off-road. You win cash and sometimes cars from AI drivers you compete against. Warning here- this is another game where the AI cars can bump you off the road, spin you out and all that while they are about totally resistant to anything you do to them. A wreck may cost you 10 or more seconds to recover from but the AI cars hardly slow down when they wreck. There are 'missions' you do along the way to earn money and some of them are kind of dumb, too. but they pay. There is an 'assist the cops' and 'run from the cops' ability that nets you special decals and a cop car at some point. A treasure hunt is included where you find pieces of cars that once assembled become yours. These include a Cobra Daytona Coupe, Cobra SC 427, a 70 Charger, VW Beetle, an Audi, and a few others. There are a number of DLC cars and motorcycles as well. There is a paint shop of sorts but you can't do any physical customizing like tires/wheels, window tint, wings, ground effects, etc. Only paint/stickers. You can start a club and compete with other clubs and if you have enough money and reputation the club gets special cars to share with club members. But good luck there because there is no way to communicate with other club members unless you all happen to be on-line at the same time so event planning tends to fail and the clubs don't seem to last. My own few club interaction experiences were closer to demolition derbys and gang warfare than car races. There are what are called Community Racing Centers with player created challenges in the game. Both are things you are supposed to do- make challenges and compete in them. Early on in the game they were so full of cheating it was a sad joke. They're supposed to be better now and the easy cheats fixed but I can't get psyched about trying them again and not messing with them has zero effect on the game being fun.  There are the player vs player and leade board challenges, too, both at spots throughout the map and immediately initiated by a flash of headlights. Again, in the early days of the game, one of the cheats had the ability to stop the clock during a race so all the leader boards show course times of 0.00.00 going hundreds and hundreds deep. It's not just impossible to beat such times, but the boards have never been cleaned off that I know of. so nobody stands a fair chance. Players used multiple IDs, set a time and never bring that record setting player back online to accept any challenges. If that's important stuff to you, I don't know what to say. At the end of the game, it's just done in an anti-climactic sort of way. There are no more missions, no more 'new' races and there's nothing new to do. It's all "make your own fun" after that. There are still ways to make money- you can re-race every event you ran as often as you like. You can make money for driving semi-recklessly - right on the centerline - or some fields make money bouncing around in an off-road car. It's slow going but you can earn money to keep buying and modifying cars up to the limits of the garage spaces you have. Oh yeah, you have to buy houses with garage slots to store your cars... You get the idea.Stiill, even with not a lot left to do, it is full open world and you do have some cool cars to cruise around in which is a ball in itself and why I keep playing it again and again.  All the fun of a driving game without the pressure to do anything but drive around!

												Atari is gone, long live Atari! Playing this game requires registration on TDU2 site, which is supposedly dead, but still allows you to register (woohoo). Graphics are primitive, music selection is limited, having an avatar in a racing game is awkward, but its still fun.If you don't own it already, I can't really recommend this game. DLCs are ridiculously expensive (they apparently still take your money for it, and no, steam $ won't do). But if you own it, hop in and lets play! :D

content:
y 2, 2014
												Starts out realy fun untill that fun starts to vapourize.  Seamless blending of multiplayer and single player is a bold claim made while in actual fact if the multiplayer servers are down you cannot play single player or anything.  The driving tests become impossible when you hit Hawaii mostly due to the vehicles supplied for the A class licence has the most terrible handling and will spin out of controll.  The vehicle upgrades improve performace of the said vehicle but offer not much in encouragement to upgrade.  You simply select from a list of leveled upgrades.  Often times you will find yourself googling for some answers as to how to do something as not everything is intuitive.  Driving around Ibiza or Hawaii you will often find what you think are challenges you can enter, which are infact multiplayer challenges that upon entering you soon find 0 online sessions, or ones you cannot join so in essence nobody seems to be hosting multiplayer challenges other than the instant challenges you can get from other players as you encounter them in the game.  The way to make money is to do the single player chalenges which there are plenty of but that hardly seems like a reason to have the multiplayer aspect in the first place.  And with the publisher layoffs how long with the servers be available.  Is it worth buying even if its on sale, no not realy.  Invest your money into something else.

This game (IF they kept updating it and kept it alive) could of been NFS Killer, I played nothing BUT this game, I didn't even consider playing NFS while I had this game. I really hope that they fix this game now, this was the best racing game of its time.

content:
ber 9, 2016
												Let me start off by first saying: yes this game definitely has its problems. It can also sometimes take quite a bit of work to get it going. I cannot guarantee that it'll be worth it for some players because everyone has their own idea of what they want from a game like this. The reason I say this is because for the main part it doesn't do a whole lot of new things especially when it comes to racing but the way it blends it all together is for sure something really nice with the social and living open world aspect to it, it can really draw you in. I often became indulged upon just roaming around the streets in my favourite car discovering new places, unlocking things & finding collectibles especially because of the encouragement you're given by the leveling system to do so. This isn't anything particularly unique now however and may wear off quick if you've already done these in similar games. Being able to buy your own house, customise and roam around in it as you please including admiring your car collection in the garage definitely added a lot to the game and makes it that little bit special even if you didn't end up spending all that much time in it.People complain about the servers but I honestly never had many issues with them (instant challenges worked fine but proper multiplayer races I never managed to get working, not sure whether it's possible or not) I struggled to get the game launched more often. Sometimes it'd decide to launch other times it didn't and I often found restarting your PC would do the trick if it refused to launch multiple times in a row. Other problems included: pink tyre marks, performance issues (which I found could be weirdly fixed by tabbing out when loading and tabbing back in again), DLC or the verification servers not working at times so literally anyone could play the DLC whether they've purchased it or not (best fault ever?) & some cars driving would be kinda glitchy. I also found the cars in some classes were a lot superior to others meaning you could either buy the best one or suffer with the rest (especially in A1) this is just my opinion however and I know many would probably disagree.If you're willing to put the effort in to make this game work and are a fan of open world racers I'd say give it a shot. I got real addicted to this game for a few weeks. (I'm using Win7, based on what I've read I think it may be harder to get it running in OS like Win10).

y 13, 2016
												So Test Drive Unlimited 2 is a game that has been out for a long time now, and I still remember the excitement when playing it for the first time; now almost 5 years after the release of the game I still find it pretty fun and exciting to play! I love the ability to just sit in a car, plug in a steering wheel and drive around Ibiza without having to race, listening to amazing and calm soundtrack, and if I want to race I just progress through the story. I have to admit the game does not have as much people playing it anymore, but the game is very old. The servers occasionally go down, but Eden Studios is doing their best to keep the servers up. I do still recommend the game, and if anyone is having a problem running the game there are go arounds on the forums, you just need to search for them.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2016
												In this I both have postive and negative opinions, so read on if you wish so.This game has a place in my heart. I got it in 2011 on the PS3 and it was fantastic. The feel of picking my character, driving my car and getting miffed off when I failed the licenses. This game will take some work to finish it, but you can download a save. If you are looking for a game, to drive around, just cruise innocently, this is for you. If you are worrying about graphics, I can run it on my AMD 7850K alone, with an avg. 62/63 fps on very low and an avg. 25/26 on very high. However, since the bloody servers went down for good, the game just doens't have that same feel. It feels, dead, almost. Yes, you can cruise around, but you cannot meet anyone else and make a club, drive around with your friends, etc. The game doesn't have that same ring to it. I'm surprised the game is even still for sale, and at £14.99, I'd avoid it at that price. I got this in the sale for £3.74 I think. The game isn't even worth over £10 anymore. The developers have laid off the game entirely and abandoned it. To be honest, TDU3 would be nice seeing *wink*. The online servers aren't even up I don't think. I think the developers lost a battle in court or something, but I'm not sure.Overall thoughts:This is genuinley a fantastic game. The driving is a bit 'meh', but still driveable. The euphoria I sometimes experienced when driving on the coast in my Audi R8, was unreal. I have so much nostalgia for this. Back to my thoughts on this, TDU2 isn't worth paying £14.99 for. Get it in the sale, when it is considerably cheaper. Overall, I would recommend this game.

content:
y 24, 2016
												I was 10 years old when Test Drive Unlimited 1 came out. I remember playing it, having no idea what to do. I grinded and grinded until I finally got that McLaren F1, which was sitting in the most beautiful house in the game. That was the most amazing feeling ever while playing a game, which is why I played the first TDU for about 2000 hours. When I heard TDU2 was announced, I was really happy. I pre ordered the retail version and played 2500 hours on it. I met a lot of people, I was part of a club that cruised with eachother every single week, I made friends. The Test Drive Unlimited series is a big part of my life, I loved it so much I decided to buy the Steam version as well, because I'm an achievement fapper. After I got all of those, I still play on a regular base.To me, it doesnt matter the servers are ♥♥♥♥, they still work, but every now and then they are offline. Dont let it bother you, just continue playing offline while the servers are down, they'll be up after a few days.To me, this is the perfect game, and I hope BigBen Interactive don't ♥♥♥♥ up Test Drive Unlimited 3. Please be good.

er 27, 2014
												To start off with i coudn't play the game for the first 10 hours because ther servers crashed because of the steam sale, but, now to get to the review.Terrible for pc unless you have a controller or something of the sorts. I spent a majority of this game changing key bindings. I started off the game not knowing how to make my character walk, because supposedly PC still uses arrow keys, and then driving your car uses arrow keys. Not a big deal, changed them to WASD. But it get's worse, you can't bind keys to your mouse buttons(or buttons on side of mouse if you have them). I was planning on putting the gear changes on my 2 side buttons but was unable to. The menus are clunky and have pointless slow annimations and a terrible resolution changer. Also there's no "fullscreen borderless".The next few hours we're average and dull. Would not reccomend.

y 8, 2015
 One heck of a game, with some flaws TDU2 is unique. It's sort of like Forza Horizon with better open-world and more realism. It's got a racing storyline, with some open-world elements to allow you to explore the beautiful islands of Hawaii (no, not Kawaii) and later on in the game (spoiler)  Ibiza . It's a console port that's mostly well done but needs some peformance tweaks.  Pros   Good graphics Very good range of cars Large and I mean  LARGE  maps x 2  Hidden easter eggs (e.g wrecked cars, collect them all and you get a car Suprisingly decent upgrade and customisation sysem  Cons  
 Securom DRM is complete and utter ♥♥♥♥ Slight framerate drops Multiplayer is down quite often Unplayable with a keyboard and mouse Physics takes gettin used to No sequel as the company has been disbanded

												Test Drive Unlimited 2 will always be my favourite racing game; even so it got some tremendous drawbacks now.You should just buy the game on steam if:- you don't own a CD copy of it already / own one but want to get it on steam for your collection- you can live without the Multi-player (because the servers are down most of the time)- you enjoy cruising around on beautiful islands- it's on sale or cheap to get somewhere else - you love "realistic" physicsIn my opinion the game is still quite some fun even so it's not what it used to be anymore. I can only play it on the lowest game setting because otherwise the game crashes every 30 minutes. (It's still enjoyable).

content:
y 7, 2014
												This game does not work at all for me. I've spent 2 weeks (every day) trying to get this game to work and still can't make it work.First issue I had was Atari's UPlauncher updates were conflicting with Steam and Steam would not allow the game to run without it's own updates installed but Atari kept overwriting it. Atari's solution, instead of releasing a patch, they just posted a workaround in their screwed up website which didn't help me at all, Steam also gave advice on how to fix the issue which also didn't work for me. I ended up resorting to trying a third party launcher which bypasses that b.s. and force the game to just launch, which it did but then crashes at the first windowed loading screen giving me a choice to send an error report which brings me to...Second issue. I tried fixing that windowed loading screen crash by downloading a non-steam version of the game through torrent and just using my legit key for it, tried old cracked offline version, tried old legit (non-cracked) offline version, tried up-to-date legit (non-cracked) online version, none of them could get passed the windowed loading screen. And this issue has no solution at all for it. Both Atari and Steam have not mentioned anything about this issue. I tried contacting Atari several times through their website support page but every time I clicked submit, an error page kept coming up so even their website is screwed up... so unprofessional of them to do this.My computer more than meets the minimum requirements for this game and yet it does not work at all for a lot of ppl including myself. This is by far the most broken game I have ever had to deal with so far. Wasted my money on a game that cannot be played no matter how much I try to fix their problems.Also, keep in mind that although I was able to receive my cd key fine, thousands of ppl right now can't get their key because Steam ran out of them and Atari doesn't care to make more because I think their business is shut down or something... so this game is in such rough condition that it probably should never have been developed by Atari at all and released on Steam in this condition. This game had a lot of potential and could have been so much more as most reviewers have pointed out, but Atari killed it.EDIT: Hmm... all of a sudden it works now... no conflicts with Steam and no crashes... after I had given up trying to fix it. Will completely redo this review later when I have some play time.EDIT: Ugh... it stopped working again... like... seriously?EDIT: got it working after realizing it was conflicting with an fps counter called Riva Tuner (comes with my video card drivers)... will edit this review later. But I still don't have nice things to say about the game though.

content:
17, 2012
												When is a racing game not just a racing game? When it's Test Drive Unlimited 2. Not a sim and not an arcade racer, TDU2 falls somewhere in the middle, offering a massive open-world to explore with over 100 vehicles to do that with, from modest to exotic. For those who need to kick back, TDU2 offers many social features, and even a casino. With all of your hard-earned cash, you’ll be able to purchase new houses, vehicles, furniture, clothing and for some reason, even a haircut and plastic surgery. The game's traditional race championships and missions alone can take 60+ hours to complete, but if you're a completionist like me, don't expect to put this down until you've amassed well over 100 hours. For all it delivers, TDU2 has proven to be one of my favorite racers ever.I reviewed the game at Techgage: : http://techgage.com/article/test_drive_unlimited_2/

y 3, 2015
												A curiously empty experience now that the online elements are no longer supported. Lots of icons on the landscape that you will never get any value out of. You see bots around the place, probably designed to give the illusion of multiplayer activity during down times. Who knew they were racing against the machine back in the day? No way to tell.The driving is OKish. The competitions are a bit one sided, at least to begin with. Either you win easily (90% of the time) or the AI does. There are no close finishes, effectively no actual racing. If you don't make a mistake you will most likely win. AI cars are glued to the track. No barging them off to gain places.The game tries hard to be "cool" but it's like a fifty year old dressing like a teen and getting it all wrong.Shame.

content:
1, 2014
												I just can'trecommend this game. I want to, on some level. but I can't.If you are like me and just would like to play offline, what you get is a driving game with very poor physics, very lite content, and a huge amount of pay walls. I really dislike seeing DLC I don't have access to. All the good cars are basically DLC.Now suppose you started playing "offline" and you suddenly have the urge to play "online". Well in this instance you have to start a new game. There is a way to use your previous save but, really, doing even that much work is just stupid. Then there is the "characters". Two Islands filled with the douchy-est characters I've ever seen in a game. Its just awful, even for the time it was released. Keyboard is near impossible to use, which would have been fine for a game leaning more to the "sim" side of things, but for an arcade racer, it seems lazy. Keyboard doesn't need to be the focus, but at least they could have thought about it.The physics themselves are okay right up to the point you lose traction. Even with a wheel, breaking loose is pretty much unrecoverable. Cars will also randomly barrel-role in a jump. That actually seems to be on purpose so you can get points. Just avoid the game. Its just not that great but also the way DLC was handled is just terrible. I'm fine with paid DLC but I prefer having a whole complete product first then adding value on top of that, instead of slicing bit off for more money.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
7, 2015
(Before I start this review, I'd like to preface it by saying I STRONGLY recommend playing this game with a gamepad, and not a KBM. Otherwise, you're in for a very bad time)IntroductionTDU2 is a very unique game. It's a driving game with heavy emphasis on social elements, such as real estate, clubs, clothing, and even (wait for it) hairstyles. That being said, I wouldn't see why anyone would want to play this offline, as most of the fun is found online. It was very buggy and otherwise a forgettable game at launch, but after numerous patches, both official and unofficial, I can certainly say that this game has had most of the kinks ironed out, and it's now a playable and fun game. TDU2 features more than 80 vehicles, miles and miles of drivable area, and several game modes for you to enjoy.Content- 8/10This game features a little over 80 cars (more if you count mods, DLC, and prize cars), ranging from humble little cars like the Volkswagen Golf, to explosive hypercars such as the Bugatti Veyron. However, I will say something about the selection of cars in this game, and that is that I am very disappointed in the bias of cars. There are literally FIVE Pagani Zondas for you to choose from, 10 Ferraris, 4 Bugatti Veyrons, but not a single Honda, Mazda, or Toyota? Now that's just biased as hell. I would honestly rather be able to drive a preppy car like a Mazda RX7, Honda Civic, or Toyota Supra than I would some insane hypercar like the Ferrari 599XX, which almost guarantees that I'm going to crash it while going 250MPH, thanks to this game's ridiculous driving physics. The game does allow for you to explore more than 100 miles of in game area, spanning two islands, Hawaii and Ibiza, as well as several in game shops and points of interest. Still, I feel like the game would be a bit more enjoyable if the physics didn't make me so prone to crashing. Speaking of the physics, let's talk about them real quick.Gameplay- 6/10Initially, I found the physics to be extremely jarring. The start of the game requires you to drive Tess, the game's main antagonist, to her photoshoot in her daddy's Ferrari. Every teenage boy's wet dream, right? Well, yeah, if I could actually drive the car without smashing it into every single corner. The cars in this game are able to accelerate very quickly, but holy hell, the braking and handling is just AWFUL. It literally felt like I was playing a 2011 version of Outrun, except I was in a much faster Ferrari, and the b!tch was yelling at me to slow the F down every 5 seconds. After finally making it to the photoshoot, my "avatar" (who is literally the most metrosexual person I've ever seen, holy hell) descended from the vehicle, along with the damsel in distress, and were quickly escorted into the building. After that, I was given a quick walkaround of my now smashed to hell and back Ferrari, and then the screen faded into the "cutscene".You can get into police chases and races and all that good stuff, so I guess the actual gameplay is very redeeming.Let me give a quick piece of advice about the player models/storyline in this game: ignore it. Pretend it doesn't exist. Pretend you're playing Forza Horizon on the PC, I don't really care. Just do whatever it takes to get past this game's godawful acting.Audio - 3/10Oh my god. Ohhhhh my god. The voice acting in this game. Oh my f*ck. Eden Games would've done a better job having Microsoft Sam voice all the characters in this game, because at least that woulda been rather funny. But this? Jesus H. Christ. Why must all the characters in this game talk like *gasp* THIS? (Pretend that I'm flicking my wrist in the most gay way possible as I'm saying that). Like seriously, you think Dragon Age Inquisition catered too much to the gay crowd? Not even close, sweetheart, this game is a whole new level of metrosexual. I'm talking this game will pimpslap you if it sees you trying to play without wearing Michael Kors pants and a Gucci suit.As if the voice acting weren't bad enough, the ingame music is just plain garbage, as if the guy who was hired to pick the music had to meet some sort of racial quota, so he went on World Star Hiphop and picked out the most Liberal sounding music he could find. Other than mediocre hip hop, you can choose from dad rock, or the occasional electro/house song. And that REALLY pisses me off, because the song used in the game's trailer is one of my favorite songs of all time, Ghosts 'n' Stuff by Deadmau5. And that's literally the only song in the game that won't make your ears bleed. Disappointing, isn't it? Thankfully, you can mod in your own music with a bit of effort, but the fact that that feature was included in TDU1 but NOT in TDU2, that makes me extremely mad. Honestly, I would recommend TDU over TDU2, if it weren't for the fact that Atari killed the TDU multiplayer.Graphics - 9/10The graphics are probably the most redeeming part of the game. For a 2011 game, I have to admit that these graphics are top notch, and I'm pretty sure even FM3 or GT5 didn't look THIS good. However, you will need a very good computer to run it at max graphics, and I'd honestly recommend a 144hz monitor to go along with it, since you don't want to have all that motion blur when driving your car around Ibiza at 250 MPH. One of the super unique features of this game is that you can actually get into a car dealer and look around your car, get inside, start the engine, open the doors, and even roll down the windows. How many games allow you to roll down the windows? Almost none. The surrounding environment is very lush and vivid, certainly FAR better than the grayish brown filter that seems to be employed in almost all modern racing games. However, about the graphics, the game doesn't go into very much detail with car damage. You can scrape up your car, get it muddy, and crack a window or two, but that's about it. I understand that the licensers (i.e. Ferrari, Bugatti, Koenigsegg) don't want to see their precious 2 million dollar hypercars getting thrashed about, but it still breaks the immersion a bit. Speaking of immersiveness, you can visually upgrade your car to a certain extent by adding vinyls, paint, and rims, but that's about it. I understand that the licensers don't want their cars being adorned with pink neon and 30" spinners, but again, it kinda breaks the immersion.Multiplayer - 9/10I gotta admit, the multiplayer is one of the coolest parts about this game. One of the best features from my favorite game, NFS Underground 2, is that you can challenge another racer at any time simply by pulling up behind them and flashing your hi beams. This is also implemented in TDU2, and you can even set your own wager, giving a new meaning to "big dog on the block". Other than that, you can spiff up your "avatar" (I really, really hate that word. Why can't we say "player" or "racer"?) by buying him new hats, glasses, suits, pants, gloves, and hairstyles, to really wow your friends/opponents. You can also buy your own pad to REALLY wow them, ranging from the basic trailer park, to the all inclusive 300' yacht. All in all, I must say that the MP is really a great example of how a racing MMO is PROPERLY done, and I'd definitely recommend this game over NFS World or HEAT Online.Closing Notes & Final ScoreAll in all, TDU2 is a very unique concept for the racing genre, and defnitely a step in the right direction for MMOs as a whole. The in game music and player models are absolute @$$, but if you can look past them, then I'm certain you'll have plenty of fun with TDU2FINAL SCORE - 7/10 Great

content:
y 12, 2014
												Possibly the worst game I've ever had the misfortune to own. Played the first version of this game on the Xbox 360, and really enjoyed it. So when I bought my gaming PC, I was keen to purchase TDU2. Bought the game in the Autumn 2013 sale for about £3, and wow, do I feel completely ripped off. After spending some time trying to get the game working (the servers are down apparently, and doesn't look like a temporary problem), I was hugely disappointed when it did actually manage to start. Game play (what little of it I actually managed to achieve was simply dire). Poor controls, car control is akin to driving games from the 8 bit era. Totally disgusted that I spent £3 on this. I'd have felt better if I'd have been scammed out of £100s by criminals. If like me, you find yourself tempted, hit the steam forums for the game, read the reviews, and if you still feel like buying it, well, don't say I didn't warn you!

"SO I SEE YOU NEED A HAIRCUT."One of the best open-world racing game? Definitely agree. How to give you image of this game? Easily - Imagine infinite highway with few cars, straight like a Route 66 and car of your dreams. Probably best description of this game. More than 100 cars to drive, from Ferrari to Mercedes and Audi. From Jaguar to Alfa and evne Lancia, Citroen and much more. And where you landing? Oh man, none other than Hawaii & Ibiza. Tropic islands full of straight, curved, clean highways and roads, off-roads, mountains, forest and many more beautiful places, & awesome views. Story is there just because somebody wants it there. It has no relevant point, I would say it is only there to make some point of making money and basically keep on living. You can style your character from eyebrows to hairstyle, and of course your clothes. Big up for me goes to the houses. There are small, medium, big. Huts, sh*tholes, mediocre flats, wooden houses or luxurious mansions and cribs. You can even own a boat where is underwater garage that let you store there those beautiful machines...I do not own Casino DLC yet, but I bought few of DLC vehicles, and it is not like you are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to pay for them and they should be in the game. For me it was pleassure to have them there.The worst thing of all is, that multiplayer is dead. It's sad, but it's truth. At least we can be very HAPPY that Atari runs those servers for those few players that are in. I wonder when they turn off servers which won't be that far, and then multiplayer will be really dead. By this I want to say TD3.In fact, I love this game. I love it more than any racing game or any of NFS series. I love it more than any Dirt or CMR... Only relevant rival would be The Crew from Ubi. But we'll see.UPDATE 1: Casino DLC is good, but to be honest it is not worth 8 euros. With the current state of Multiplayer definitely not.UPDATE 2: Cloud Support - none. Atari Support tells you to play a new game, because it is not long game.UPDATE 3: Atari sold it to BigBen.Bonus Point: Atari still running the serversRating: 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												There may be a few things that you may consider "Spoilers" in this review.     In all honesty, this is an.. "Decent" game.  This coming from someone who's never played the first game, I have mixed feelings, and thoughts about the differences between the two products.  Anyway, I will give you my honest impressions on this game after having it for a year or so.  This game greets you with absolutely beautiful graphical detail, and very accurate vehicale models.  This game simulates modern, and classic vehicles in a very accurate manner, along with accurate prices too. (Most of the time.)       There are many ways to earn money in this game, some more convenient than others, some more fun than others.  One is by completing the Solar Crown Championships, which require certain vehicle types to participate in.  Now, let me say this... I DO NOT recommend attending the championships, unless you enjoy completing some of the most repetitive, monotenous acts I've ever seen.  I mean, most of them are common in a lot of racing games today, however, I just feel they are just wasted potential here.  I would have enjoyed seening the type of racing like in Midnight Club 3, which is an amazing game made by Rockstar if you didn't know.        A more convinient way of earning a bit of cash is by using F.R.I.M. F.R.I.M is a system that gives you a small amount of money for doing simple things, such as having a near miss with another driver, or constantly drifting. (It gives you $100 dollars when you start, and the money increases then.  I believe the maximum you can get in one run is $10,000.)        Another way to earn money is to race other drivers you find around the area.  The will have a random name, and flashing you headlights at them will allow you to race them instantly.  You can race the same person until you grow tired of it, so if you find that one person that has no chance of winning, you can make VERY easy money for as long as you please.     Now, for those of you who enjoy driving you valuable vehicles like a sane human being, the cockpit view is very detailed, and flows well with the overall control scheme, and graphical style.  Although, if you hate slow AI drivers, than here's something to note.  TDU2 has some of the dumbest civilian AI I've ever seen.  The are just about the slowest driver AI as well.  You just need to play the game to see.     Another note, if you want to play this game with a friend, I have some bad news.  Because of the developer studio shutting down, the multiplayer servers went with them.  It's worth searching whether a multiplayer mod will be made for this game, like the one made for Just Cause 2.  (If you have any information on that, please tell me.  I'd be willing to play online with someone.)     With all that aside, I can't help but go back to this game because of the sharp visuals, and lovely selection of vehicles to choose from.  The sounds are wonderful, the thrill of have a 1.6 million dollar car keeps you playing, exploring the island(s), and finding landmarks.    With that said, I do recommend this game, just be aware of some of the "Moments" that the AI has, and some of the short- comings of the physics engine.I give this game a Seven out of Ten, and I do recommend it to anyone who wants a good-looking, mixture of arcade fun, and realistic simulation.Thank you.

content:
ry 13, 2014
												Its a great game if you are into simply driving for the heck of it and exploring the open road... but if you expect this to be a bit of "gran turismo" mixed with debutaunte social goals [as i thought from watching the trailers] you will be sadly mistaken....the Dev team that put this together did an EXCELLENT job creating a world in which a player can explore and have fun in with a HUGE open environment; however, this environment is marred by the fact that the physics in the game are only passable if you  play perfectly.  Example being in interaction with other vehicles on the roads, hit them and you come to a dead stop... take a corner too rough and at least the game forgives a bit and will spin you as expected.   Other glaring faults I consider are that the voice acting leaves a LOT to be desired, the motivation of the characters are extremly questionable, the amount of customization is lacking in variety, & finally the "unlocking" scheme is laughable.VOICE ACTIINGvoice acting in just cause 2 was ten times better than this... just mentioning it.Character/Story Developmenton a chance encounter mission this lady is at the side of the road in one of the major cities, and decides to ask some yabbo in a VW scirocco to take her Pagani Zonda to the mechanic shop because she doesnt have the time to... oh and dont scratch it... Customizationto be honest i have not even bothered, primarily because the "stickers" are a load of... and the tech shop is really all that is needed... I have not played the game long enough to comment on the impact that owning a mc-mansion has on gameplay nor needing to buy that poolside valet bar stool thingy that apaprently i can impress other TDU2 gamers with... to me this is the equivalent of getting Recon armor in halo, or Bedazzled guns in COD franchise, or worse still a bee in a bottle from Zelda franchise.... Unlocking itemsAgain... having not played far enough to really get a sense of what is available I looked forward into FAQS and guides and saw that a player needs to to unlock the privilege to buy cars in game... nuff said... Whatever!!! in conclusion... the only selling point that this game brought to the table that i willingly thought would make it all worth it.. the open world aspect of being able to drive absolutely EVERYWHERE!! thats the only good thing about this worth mentioning...if you are looking for realism... look elsewhereif you are seeking an arcade-ish experience... look elsewhereif you want a decent story or plausible real life mimicry... look elsewhereif you are looking for an open world game that ~~promises a lot of potential~~ to drive various cars around a massive island while in the same time extremely slowly rising through the ranks of a Dubai-esque racing series with possible androids masquerading as humans... then this may be the game for you!!!

content:
er 28, 2013
												The last time I played a Test Drive game was probably in 2000, with Test Drive 2. At the time, I gave it up for Need for Speed 3, which was significantly superior.   I chuckled to myself as I bought this game, thinking how times have changed. Now, I am officially done with Need for Speed. I have had enough of dealing with EA's barely-deliverable products. (As a fun time-waster, try emailing their tech support. It doesn't matter what question you ask because it certianly won't be the question they answer.)  But now, I'm not so sure. The lack of attention to detail, which is exactly why I decided to leave Test Drive all that time ago, is still present in this newest game. I am frustrated that a pitiful light post is able to stop a 3000+ pound car cold, and the frustration only grows when it takes the driver a significant number of seconds to get his ♥♥♥♥ back together and ease the car into reverse. I would be satisfied if the car were wrecked by the light pole, but at least continued rolling.The cars could also probably do with a new set of tires. I have occasionally slid vehicles on ice, even been stuck and had to walk home, but, before this day, I have never managed to slide a full 360 in rain.  One of the reviews already posted admitted that this was not a game for racing enthusiasts, which leaves me wondering... Who is it a game for? Is it Club Penguin, but with cars?  At first glance (which was enough to get me to buy it), the game seems solid, but it is the collection of every little thing wrong with it that makes it, in my mind, a complete waste of time, not to mention money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2013
												This game is really poor.The driving physics are the sort of thing you'd expect from a ps1 game. Other than looking at the speedo you can't really gauge or feel how fast you're going. You can't really drift on this game very well, which is stupid since it's something which you can use to earn money within the game. If you lose internet connection it will take you to the title screen and when you attempt to play again it will just make you watch loading screens without actually letting you play... it just takes you back to the title screen after a while because you have no connection (and carries on in a cycle). The online players as well as the pedestrian cars/bikes glitch a lot and jerk forwards like 200 yards up the road at times. I know it's not exactly a brand new game at this point, but the graphics really aren't anything worth shouting about.If you have the sort of expectations of this game that I had, i.e. something which offers a good open-world driving experience similar to that of need for speed games, but with more realistic handling, better graphics and the sort of gameplay that wouldn't get boring quickly, you'll be entirely disappointed.And also worth a mention is the pain in the ♥♥♥ installation...AFter downloading via steam it not only makes you sign up to their website to create an account for the game (hardly the end of the world, I know, but there's more to come), you have to activate the game with a serial key (something I haven't had to do with any other steam game), when you try to launch the game it will make you download another gigabyte of data (probably files which make the game as crap as it is), which WILL fail to download... at which point you should refer to this:http://support.atari.com/index.php?/Knowledgebase/Article/View/76/0/i-am-receiving-error-5which should fix the problem for you, but in all honesty you'd be better not buying the game and saving yourself the hassle/disappointment

content:
y 8, 2016
												I got this game massively on the cheaps in the year end sale and it was worth every penny.  I wondered how the servers would be, but they've been "mostly fine" but I've built up my offline profile to match my online one "just in case" - besides sometimes I want to be online and sometimes I don't.I got a wheel/peddles for Christmas and it has been a BLAST playing, although when I upgraded one of my cars, my wheel "tightened up" to the point where it nearly started smoking (even tho I've got the FF on LOW) with heavy use.  My profile where I didn't do the upgrade doesn't have the problem.  I wish I could go back to an earlier save to get rid of that upgrade!The price of DLC for this game is ridiculous - that won't be happening.  The game is nice though, I have read plenty of whining about the voice actors/animations/story line - that is part of the charm of gaming and doesn't bother me in the least.  The cars are fun to drive and the maps are amazing.  That's what matters.

												Pros:Plays wellHandling is not arcadey but not simulator eitherLooks goodDecent visual customizationTwo massive islands to explore with a bunch of stuff to findA fair amount of cars (no Mazdas though >:| )Cons:Repetitive as well as godawful radio station soundtracks where they tried to be like GTA with parody ads. Except they forgot the funny.Grindy story with no varietyServers are iffy at best. Hard to play with friends sometimes.While the races are painfully easy (no challenge at all if you are even remotely decent), the liscense challenges (which are COMPLETELY UNNECCESSARY. I have NEVER used ANYTHING from the schools in the actual races) are painfully difficult and are really the only thing that will slow progress.It's pretty much dead in the competitive scene. No Club VS Club, no multiplayer challenges, nothing. Hope you got some friends to boost with.I say get it when it's on sale. I don't just play a game for 180+ for nothing.

content:
1, 2014
												READ FOR A HONEST REVIEWI had this game on my Xbox for at least a year. Finally when I got older I had the right mind to build a computer. My specs are more than the requirements for the game. Gameplay wise, the game is exellent. I love the driving expierience, you can buy cars, buy houses, and the free roam is exellent. The car variety is amazing, and the level of detail, and sounds for each car, is amazing. On Xbox at least. I only was able to play for 3 hours on my computer due to how bad the game is. The textures are horrible, things dissapear, and the game freezes. After all that, I figured I would still give the game a chance due to my love for cars, and my great Xbox expierience in the past. However apon start, I was presented with a "Corrupted Savegame" message. Are you kidding me? In the three hours I played, I had over $300,000 and 3 cars. I cant play this game, for the $8 I spent it was not even worth it. I can't even think about playing this game anymore. When I filed a ticket on the Atari website, they responded with "Well you played the game once, so it should be easier to replay it again" How about you and eDen actually fix the god damn problem instead of telling me to go pound sand. Please don't waste your money on this game. There are many other great games that you can buy instead. If you do get the game to work, I envy you, because I wish I could get mine to work.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2013
												A continuum of a very open, unique, marvelous game Test drive unlimted. I started playing this series on the Playstation 2 and really loved how open and challeging it was. It's not like the other generic racing games where you just race a couple of times and instantly get a $1,000,000+ supercar. You have to work for hours upon hours in order to advance even a small percentage.  Even though I found it gets a bit harder in my opinion to earn money in Test drive unlimited 2 then the first one, I have found no annoying bugs, glitches or other major problems while playing it. The main things I think could be improved would be server downtime and NPC's (They act a bit awkward at times). The server downtime can get annoying on people who just started playing so that is why I recommend playing in offline mode first before you go out and "show-off" your cars and items. If you don't know how to start in offline mode just ask me and I'll help. Overall the game is very good, but I wish they didn't remove or change some elements that were in the original. I sort of feel for Atari though, as they are in financial trouble and really can't help with server issues, rushing development of the game, etc. The game obviously can be improved greatly but as of right now it is very good and I love it! 9.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												There may be a few things that you may consider "Spoilers" in this review.     In all honesty, this is an.. "Decent" game.  This coming from someone who's never played the first game, I have mixed feelings, and thoughts about the differences between the two products.  Anyway, I will give you my honest impressions on this game after having it for a year or so.  This game greets you with absolutely beautiful graphical detail, and very accurate vehicale models.  This game simulates modern, and classic vehicles in a very accurate manner, along with accurate prices too. (Most of the time.)       There are many ways to earn money in this game, some more convenient than others, some more fun than others.  One is by completing the Solar Crown Championships, which require certain vehicle types to participate in.  Now, let me say this... I DO NOT recommend attending the championships, unless you enjoy completing some of the most repetitive, monotenous acts I've ever seen.  I mean, most of them are common in a lot of racing games today, however, I just feel they are just wasted potential here.  I would have enjoyed seening the type of racing like in Midnight Club 3, which is an amazing game made by Rockstar if you didn't know.        A more convinient way of earning a bit of cash is by using F.R.I.M. F.R.I.M is a system that gives you a small amount of money for doing simple things, such as having a near miss with another driver, or constantly drifting. (It gives you $100 dollars when you start, and the money increases then.  I believe the maximum you can get in one run is $10,000.)        Another way to earn money is to race other drivers you find around the area.  The will have a random name, and flashing you headlights at them will allow you to race them instantly.  You can race the same person until you grow tired of it, so if you find that one person that has no chance of winning, you can make VERY easy money for as long as you please.     Now, for those of you who enjoy driving you valuable vehicles like a sane human being, the cockpit view is very detailed, and flows well with the overall control scheme, and graphical style.  Although, if you hate slow AI drivers, than here's something to note.  TDU2 has some of the dumbest civilian AI I've ever seen.  The are just about the slowest driver AI as well.  You just need to play the game to see.     Another note, if you want to play this game with a friend, I have some bad news.  Because of the developer studio shutting down, the multiplayer servers went with them.  It's worth searching whether a multiplayer mod will be made for this game, like the one made for Just Cause 2.  (If you have any information on that, please tell me.  I'd be willing to play online with someone.)     With all that aside, I can't help but go back to this game because of the sharp visuals, and lovely selection of vehicles to choose from.  The sounds are wonderful, the thrill of have a 1.6 million dollar car keeps you playing, exploring the island(s), and finding landmarks.    With that said, I do recommend this game, just be aware of some of the "Moments" that the AI has, and some of the short- comings of the physics engine.I give this game a Seven out of Ten, and I do recommend it to anyone who wants a good-looking, mixture of arcade fun, and realistic simulation.Thank you.

												It's a fun, MASSIVE open world game, with tonnes of licensed cars and that's not all, as well as having cars it's also basically the same as Playstation Home with the social features, you buy apartments and properties and can furnish them, invite people over, go to the casino (dlc) etc..., However the game does get pretty repetitive and the cockpit views aren't too great, they block out the beautiful scenery and your head sways left and right when you are turning hard which might cause sickness in, well, normally motion sick people. It uses a third party DRM which isn't at all hard to use, it's just five to ten minutes to make an account, sign in once and you're done.7.8/10 Great with friends, but when you're playing Single Player it can get repetitive and boring.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2013
Edit Mar 13, 2017 - Server StatusUnkown, in all likelihood will never come online again. It's no longer recommended to buy this at full-price because you're not getting the full features. Only good for offline play. Still recommended though not highly. Estimated value for money at discounted price is only 6/10End of editEdit July 1, 2016Servers aren't always on 7 days a week without downtime or maintenance; expect downtime about once a week. On a good stretch, servers can be on for weeks without any downtime; this is way better than other MMO games where servers have regular downtime at least once a week. Downtimes can last anywhere between 1 day - 1 week so try the launcher at least once daily. Alternatively, Steam forum is also a good place to check on server status.On the plus side and this is a major plus, once you're online you can sit there for hours afk or even sleep at the wheel for days if you wish without getting kicked out by the server; no other MMO game allows this ;) In other MMOs, you'll be kicked out in about 15 mins of inactivity. TDU1 and TDU2 used to be my other homes, i was like, living in there a few years ago haha.End of editOriginal brief reviewMore than just competitive racing. Two huge open worlds where you can explore almost anywhere, even drive to the mountain peaks if you are so inclined, pun intended. Despite the bugs in the game world, it is a great place for a leisurely tour with friends, or if you prefer, drive as if your life depends on it; just don't get caught by the cops.Edit July 1, 2016 - addendumNot much to complain about this game except the traffic and keyboard control. Traffic can be a pain in the rear - erm i mean front, mostly front. They can appear and disappear at will as if  thrown in front of you for no other reason than to aggravate you but what driving or racing games has perfect traffic behaviour? Keyboard control is not smooth on asphalt for cars but for bikes it's perfect. On dirt tracks, keyboard control feels natural on almost any vehicle except for sports cars.End of edit So what's so good about this game? Well there are 2 huge open free-roam worlds, that feels alive with day and night cycles, random weather with thunderstorms, birds and airplanes flying, airplane landings but i've never seen birds land on anything. No NPC ai walking about which is a good thing since my driving is all over the place. There are NPCs in the buildings though that serve as interaction points for shops. There are different kinds of shops for customizing your avatar and vehicles such clothing shops and paint shops to name a few. Showrooms and real estate agencies are also available for you to expand your car collection and buy more properties to house all your vehicles. Having many properties means you can park at any convenient location before logging off. It doesn't matter if your garage is full. Or if you're really in a hurry, you can simply logoff from anywhere in the game world.While a lot of these customizing options and services may seem like fluff, it does add to the sense of immersion and of being in a vibrant world. What sets this game apart from all other driving games are 3 things:- You can invite friends into your house- You can drive a friend around in your car or if you prefer - a stranger.- You can drive almost anywhere where there are no visible physical barriers in place. So yeah get this game, 'coz there's nothing like it, even TDU1 falls a little short. What TDU1 does better is smoother keyboard control and the ability to set a completely private session with your friends in the game world. Everything else is better in TDU2. Last but not least, it's low in price, high in content and it can be played offline. So even if the server is down you can still have your cake (game) and eat (play) it, just not the same savegame, which is more than can be said for the likes of The Crew or Elite Dangerous.

content:
28, 2015
												It might be fun for single player, but this game is pretty much dead unless you have a dedicated friend or group of friends to play with. If you don't, keep in mind that this game is pretty much single player.The good:Cruising, open world, racing, lots of cars, lots of roads, customization of avatar and car, basic tuning of cars, houses, the old tdu 1 map, the new map, offroad vehicles, motorcycles are back, and day/night & weather cycling, random encounters with some online people will result in a nice group cruise or legit race.The bad:Mainly a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ contest between most people even in open world cruising, massive amounts of cheating, cheating, more cheats, cheaters trying to impress others by cheating, cheaters trying to annoy others by cheating, dated graphics, limited tuning options (especially gear ratios), limited suspension and grip preferences for off road vehicles, and a bunch of dlc that is not worth it.I boot this game up for a casual experience and don't plan on taking it too seriously. I still find myself having fun with it doing my own thing and meeting good people while blocking or un-linking from the dips that have issues they need to sort out on their own time. Knowing this, I can't recommend this game to anyone that wants to race online, have a fun experience with all the dynamics of this game, or play this game as it was originally intended. Also, all the leader boards are jacked up. Top scores dominated by cheaters soon after the game was released. There are plenty of other solid games out there for racing/cruising/tuning.A typical experience for many:Run into a stop sign: no problem. Run into a tiny bush with flowers on it: brick wall. Decide you want to get off the road and cruise the HUGE open terrain? Sweet. Find out how difficult it is to navigate around most terrain with all the "obstacles". Finally find a nice open space to floor it. See tall wheat fields and want to frolic through them;-- stopped by a tiny wooden fence hidden in the wheat. Turn around and go back into the wilderness and punch it. Yay; car stopped dead in it's tracks by a boulder hidden by a one foot tall patch of grass. Give up and go back onto the road to giv'r. Floor it. About to hit top speed; a car spawns out of nowhere 15 ft in front of you. Decide to just cruise; a random player online decides to turn on tank mod and harass you a bit or show you how fast he/she can go and get you to ride coop to be amazed. Decide to jump to a new location; can't sync with anyone. Being lonely, you decide to take a break, call your mom, call your gf, call your dad, call your brothers/sisters, smoke it up, eat, take a poo, check your phone, take a nap, take another poo, and then boot it up in hopes of it syncing with others; 3 people online and all afk. Decide to uninstall it; you re-install it.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												So everyone knows, sure, Test Drive Unlimited 2 was released with a slew of bugs and was considered mediocre at best. Don't be fooled by this. They have added many features to the game including challenges, cars, classes of cars and many other things. I really enjoy the fact that after you get so far in Ibiza (a decent sized island), you get to fly to Hawaii to race (not sure which island). And man, that island is larger than you think. It took me 45 minutes to an hour to drive from the airport (northwest) to the southeast coast and it was at full speed (driving an Audi TTS, averaging 140-150 mph) in real time. I love the fact that you can fully explore everything on the island. A few things this game lacks: voice acting, variety of voice acting, better multiplayer matches and/or support, Atari member support, and the issue with the fact that I completed 7 DLC missions and went in today to see I completed ZERO. Annoying to start over again. So a few issues still exist. If you can find this game on sale and you love the free roam exploring aspect, buy it!

content:
21, 2015
												One of the best driving games you will ever play.This game is a mixed bag. As far as single player goes; it's a great driving game if you like time trials or just relaxing cross country driving. Singleplayer races aren't very difficult because the ai is pretty easy but a lot of the time trials and other solo challenges are fairly fun and some will require some practice. Singleplayer isn't too special, though. It's not bad but the game was clearly designed with multiplayer as the main focus.Because as for the multiplayer.. You're given the choice to either play online or offline when creating and in-game profile. If you choose to play online then you'll seemlessly see other players driving around the island that you can use voice or text chat with. Challenging other players is encouraged since you get rank points for doing things such as adding people to your friend list or doing challenges with others. There's also ai police that drive around which will get upset if you act malicious towards other drivers. Being too much of a bully will put you into a police chase and if any other players are nearby, they'll be given the choice of getting a police car and being sent after you. The fun of this feature is partially off-set by how most players drive Bugatti's and other supercars making them hard to catch but it's still a nice tough. You can also bet money against others in these challenges which adds a little more purpose.One of the best parts of the game that shines is the world compared to other driving/racing games. You're given two detailed recreations of both Ibiza and Oahu. In a lot of cases you can actually use a real map to help navigate both of the islands. There's all sorts of roads and highways and rural trails that you can drive on, and if you really want to you can just drive off the road completely. There's no invisible walls keeping you from driving off the road and nearly every mountain has a way to the top if your car can handle the slopes (and there are cars specifically meant for offroading.)To top of the world's detail.. You can go into various shops and buy clothes or haircuts or cosmetic surgery. You can walk into dealer ships to look at cars in detail and buy them and you can even buy houses and apartments. If you're playing online, you'll also see other players walking around in the public areas, otherwise you can invite them into your home for shenanigans. Here in 2015, it's no GTA Online but it's still wonderful if you're looking for a more relaxed environment where someone won't try to blow you up every few minutes. Also the soundtrack is pretty chill and varied.With that said, it's pretty much a recreational driving MMO with no monthly subscription and a cash shop that only consists of a few completely optional cars that only cost around a dollar each to unlock (the DLC only unlocks them; you still have to pay for them with ingame money so it still retains a degree of balance.) The only DLC that's mandatory for certain features is the Casino DLC which lets you gamble and win a Casino-exlusive car, and the motorcycle DLC. But seeing as DLC is very cheap, it's not too big of a deal.Tl;dr buy it if you wanna kill time with cars and endless roads. You get a ton of that pricetag of $20..Though, keep in mind that some people have a hard time setting up the mandatory account with Atari.Once you get past that, you're in for a good time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 21, 2014
												So everyone knows, sure, Test Drive Unlimited 2 was released with a slew of bugs and was considered mediocre at best. Don't be fooled by this. They have added many features to the game including challenges, cars, classes of cars and many other things. I really enjoy the fact that after you get so far in Ibiza (a decent sized island), you get to fly to Hawaii to race (not sure which island). And man, that island is larger than you think. It took me 45 minutes to an hour to drive from the airport (northwest) to the southeast coast and it was at full speed (driving an Audi TTS, averaging 140-150 mph) in real time. I love the fact that you can fully explore everything on the island. A few things this game lacks: voice acting, variety of voice acting, better multiplayer matches and/or support, Atari member support, and the issue with the fact that I completed 7 DLC missions and went in today to see I completed ZERO. Annoying to start over again. So a few issues still exist. If you can find this game on sale and you love the free roam exploring aspect, buy it!

												Let me start by saying i put over 500 hours into this game from the xbox 360 and loved it to death. I missed it so much and maxed everything out so i said hell yeah i will do it on pc too. Well the game plays really great and the driving is not perfect but each car feels different and driving around with friends is so much fun. I even made friends day one playing this the last few nights. This is an amazing cruise around and enjoy hanging out with new and old friends. There is so much to do in this game to keep you coming back. The online rarely max's out but there is always people in my game. The only huge downer for this game is the dlc which you need to buy atari tokens to buy the casino dlc and cars. I read from some they never get the tokens they paid for and the support is worthless if not dead. It seems like a huge gamble and sad they did not care to fix this stuff to work ok to buy stuff. I still think this is a must own cruise around and do random stuff. It  holds up pretty well for a old game and still is one of my favorite free roam cruise around car game. If you are super picky avoid this if you are looking for fun with others and fun stuff to find and unlock you will like it.

content:
6, 2016
												This is a good game... plagued with gamebreaking bugs, ♥♥♥♥ customer service and a pretty much dead developer.  Also the game might not even make it past the "Press Start" screen which is poor.  If you ALT tab the mouse & keyboard/controller might become unresponsive.  Lets be a bit more specific here. To get the game to start properly (get past the launcher, which is cancerous) I had to download this[i-knyazev.ru] program.  Thumbs down for that.A lot of good cars require microtransactions to unlock.  You need "Atari Coins" or some ♥♥♥♥ like that but wait...  they are broken too!  You need to buy them on the website, but navigating the tdu2.com (which now redirects to atari.com) was tumour inducing.  Sometimes the pages CSS/JavaScript would just fail completely (without a fix, leaving the barebones HTML) meaning you would have to sort through it all to find the log-in prompt.  Thumbs down for that.With all that aside, you have a pretty good game.  There is a broad selection of cars to chose from.  There are 3 types of cars Type A (sports, super and hyper cars), Type B (SUVS, trucks) and Type C (classic/old cars) with their own unique races.  Each of them have different stages.  Type A has 7 stages of cars (stage 1 would be a Koenigsegg or a Buggati, stage 7 would be a lower end Alfa Romeo.)  That might seem quite confusing but it is a thumbs up for that.The maps are pretty damn big.  Yes maps.  There is not one but two maps included:  Ibiza and Hawaii.  They are pretty much complete re-models of the real islands.  (scaled down a bit).  Most of the towns you see in the game are real towns.  The map is not as incredible as ARMAs but it is still pretty good.  Thumbs up on that.There is not much else to say.  The review started to get a bit... shoddy near the end here but it is the best I can do.  I am going to give this a thumbs down, mostly because you might have to download 3rd party software to get the game to work properly which is quite poor on Ataris part.

content:
ry 9, 2015
												I remember seeing ads for Test Drive Unlimited 2 back before it was released and being absolutely floored with the freedom and graphical fidelity promised. Several years later I had all but forgotten it’s existence when suddenly it popped up in the steam winter sale. What perfect timing! I was itching for a good open world driving game and along comes one that I had wanted so badly on sale for just a few bucks.Well 10 hours later my itch is gone, but TDU2 makes a terrible scratcher. I’m not sure if I would have been as disappointed had I picked up the game in its prime, but with the multiplayer non-existent and the game itself being an absolute nightmare to install and get running due to the servers being neglected for the past 3 or 4 years, there is little left to be loved about this game. It’s really cool to see all the car brands licensed and buying houses to decorate definitely appeals to the Sims lover in me, but finding the dealers is a pain and the game world is unfathomably massive. It’s fun to drive and the cars handle well, but the amount of mundane driving about you end up doing causes your eyes to glaze over. By the 8th or 9th hour of play I found myself watching Netflix while I systematically scour a city for a particular dealer or make my way across the world to a different race. At that point I realized it just wasn't that fun and I uninstalled it.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
28, 2014
Short version: If you want single player offline cruising, get TDU2. (for $5 when it's on sale)If you want anything else (responsive controls, racing, challenges, story mode, good overall sound track, etc) do NOT get TDU2.Long version:PROS:  two huge islands to drive around on for the sake of casual cruising.  That's it. This is the sole only reason worth playing this. If you want this and this alone in offline mode, go for it.CONS:..........  I'll just write a whole book here......"Do I want quality or quantity?"Well, this game offers a high quantity of low quality content.It has been a disaster since day 1. It was never finished (this is confirmed), what you will play is a beta profuct.- Basically no moderation. It's a cheater paradise. The few who get banned return instantly to ruin other people's games. CRC mode (challenges made by players for players) was made extinct because of this. There goes 33% replayability content of what this game was supposed to offer.- The game is on life support and held together by dry tape. A mere skeleton crew is running the servers which goes down a lot, A LOT, without any warning; you never get noticed in advance or told when it will be back up like any other well-kept game does. This was common since the beginning when they dared charge $50 for this mess. I expect Atari to pull the plug on the server unannounced very soon and you end up with an unplayable game. Some say to play it in offline mode, but what is the point of promoting an MMO (or M.O.O.R. as Atari wanted to hype it) if it is so extremely unreliable and offline a lot?  Its online feature is supposed to be a big selling point, yet it fails; oh how it fails at this. The online feature of this game is very uncertain.- Atari has behaved very unprofessional towards its customers this entire time, we get no proper feedback, no messages when the servers go down, the official forums have died a long time ago, support tickets go unanswered etc.- Your save game file is stored LOCALLY on your PC, not online. It can go corrupt at any random moment due to faulty programming, so you are expected to make a manual backup everytime you play. Doesn't happen to everybody but it happens often enough to many people in general that this is a huge game-breaking bug that was never fixed.- Difficult to play with friends due to the random 8-player session system. I had a 25% success rate to join my friends at all. Eventually they all left, I don't blame them.- After you finish the game (I did this within 1 month after release) earning money is no longer fun. It's a tedious repetitive boring grind-fest. What were they thinking removing bomb mission after you do them? They gave the game diversity at least. (they weren't thinking really, I can't list all the many bad game design decisions but they are MANY!)- No big secret here, the physics are awful awful awful. Some cars behaviour is just unexplainable. Collision reaction is just as buggy. This is an arcade car game, well it sure doesn't control as such. It feels like the air was let out of the tires. The Burnout series, the Midnight Club series, the older Need for Speed series, these are all CORRECT arcade physics games. Heh, even TDU1 has better physics. What the hell happened here in this sequel?- The AI in single player races is a joke. Your rival AI opponent rubberbands around you no matter how good or bad you drive, the rest always stay far behind. This is a big contrast to the extremely hard (& pointless) driving school sessions which may block you early at the start of the game for the average gamer. Don't be fooled what others say, you will not become a better driver by finishing them, just relived that you passed those frustration-fests.- The Sims elements is not a good meaningful addition. You will giggle about it at first, but soon it loses its luster and meaning. This is a car game, you won't be seeing your character or your houses indoors for most of the time. It was a waste of time and resources developing this Sims stuff. The time would have been better spent finalizing other more useful game features (which are broken or simply not there).- What made TDU1 good has been removed from TDU2. (too many to list here). Many steps backwards were taken.- Don't let the biased Metacritic score fool you.  That score is based on the launch condition the game was in (wasn't good back then either) and the positive thinking expectations of what it would become. Well, as time passed, the game got worse and worse. More errors/bugs were introduced instead of fixed. Force feedback got broken, innocent people getting marked as cheaters (their cars turn into Pink Mustangs), casino DLC getting more buggier, etc etc.GOOD games promise XYZ, and deliver XYZ.TDU2 promised XYZ, it delivered only X. (the goal-less cruising). The people who like X are the only ones who like this game and treat it like it's the best thing ever. That's a terrible way to review/recommend a product to others. You review THE WHOLE package, not just the part you like. Not everybody plays an openworld game for the same reasons, since you know, openworld games offer a lot of varied gameplay. But like I said, this openworld only offers X, nothing more. That makes it a very limited openworld game. TDU1 did deliver all its promised XYZ.  So if you want to cruise offline, go play that instead. It has better working finished content. Atari, or what is left of it, doesn't deserve any money from TDU2.I can only guess how many unfortunate people followed such biased misinformation and bought this thing only to rage-quit soon afterwards, having wasted their time and money. For every 1 satisfied player in this game, you will find 9 others who hate it. Just check twitter, facebook, etc etc (even these are practically dead). You will see a lot of hate, very little praise.

content:
ber 24, 2011
												Test Drive Unlimited 2 is what you would call a blatant console port, in other words a total insult to pc gamers. The kb+mouse combo just feels awkward while playing TDU2. The game also runs like ♥♥♥♥ even on high end machines; I have a 6 core AMD clocked to 3.4 GHz combined with an ATI 5850 OC edition yet I still have visible graphical lag in this game. Furthermore this is not a racing game, yes you can drive cars around, but the racing aspect in this game is just half baked. TDU2 is Eden Games attempt at emulating face-book in a pseudo-racing genre. The sad part is that your avatar/house is more customizable than your car. This games physics engine also appears to be absent. You can ram in to trucks all day, the only visible damage you will have on your car is dirt and a couple scratches. There are many more problems but I am on a 180 char limit. Just know that if you buy this game, expect to be blown away by mediocrity.

content:
y 6, 2015
												As a fan of Test Drive Unlimited 1 on XBOX 360 I was put off with all the reviews I have read when it came out so much in fact I forgot about the game until a friend of mine mentioned it during the Winter Sale 2014, He paid for himself and me a copy about £3.49 I think it was and oh boy how Atari just rushed this out and tried to get as much coin in before they went bust or to whatever state there in now. The game is terrible from the very first game car handling is out the window and is just stiff and arcady, vehicle sounds are awful mostly to me seem re used for every car but higher pitched for high end cars, the island looks ok not upgraded in visuals over TD1 as I would of thought.The story is awful your car parker guy who starts off dreaming he's been giving a Ferrari which turns out the woman who gives you it it nothing but the real owner of the car???, who then thinks she is punishing you by driving her to her destination because she's going to be late okkkkkkkkkkkk. The voice acting is terrible really poor like they just used the own devs creating the game to give the samples to save money, your player while driving the car is as stiff as a bloke getting a rectal exam it's beyond a joke.But it's the installation of the game thats a right royal pain in the backside for anyone installing it now it still has secuROM whch to me is pointless considering Atari really ain't around anymore and sometimes the online are up or down. With this game registering through STEAM why bother with SecuROM what's the point really I will be always baffled as to why games carry such things when you need to be signed into STEAM for most games they could of just gave it an always online system. In todays games we mostly are always online for multiplayer but I don't think a game like this really needs SecuROM, it took me about 30 mins to understand what to do to activate the dam game basically you copy and paste the CD KEY into the box provided to activate it and your LIMITED to 4 yes 4 ACTIVATIONS which you can earn back when you remove it but again this system is just pointless.
